Dialog.Content: Still, the highlight of the match is the woman who was once called the Red Mist… This oughta be fun.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: Everyone I meet keeps bringing up that title. Aren’t you tired of putting me on a pedestal at this point?

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: No way, hun. People’ll be shocked to learn that the great legend is doing menial labor in a place like this.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: How’s your inhuman strength doing these days?

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: I only heard stories ‘bout it, so I’ve been itching to see it in action…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: Is strength the only thing you value?

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: Yup. No reason not to bow down to folks who’re stronger than you.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: What do you think people who lack such strength should do, then?

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: The weak—they gotta find ways to survive on their own.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: You obey the strong, or you get killed by ‘em… Either or. Someone will keep you safe if you serve ‘em like a good little pup.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: There won’t be an end to a struggle fought with physical strength. It’ll be a constant series of gory battles…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: Even the victor can’t be at ease in such a world. Those who act in their own interests can lose everything by the same means at anytime.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: Is it really right to possess strength if it’s only used to take from others?

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: Ehey, why see that as stealing, gal?

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: This is just how the world is, and the ones best adapted to it come out on top, simple as that.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: Adapt or die. If you can’t, you either become food or fall behind until you’re wiped out.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: The so-called apex predators are the creatures best fit to survive in this ecosystem, ain’t that the truth?

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: That’s how humans have always lived, so why make a big fuss about it now?

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: Strength is the most honest and clear way to express yourself.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: I prove that I’m stronger than you, and that’s it. No tricks or lies involved.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: I want a world where power means everything. And that’s why I’m helping mister orchestrator.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: Oh, I guess you’ve got your own reasons and causes to bring up as well. For the sake of others, making the world peaceful, or whatevs… Not like I wanna hear ‘em.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: You prolly looked at all the people hopelessly dying n’ wanted to do something for ‘em out of pity or anxiety, but the truth is, the City folks were doing fine without ya.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: You didn’t seriously expect everyone in the City to gladly take the gift you forcibly handed to ‘em and hear thanks, didja?

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: And look at you now, ruining the daily lives of innocent people to resume your plan…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: It’s true, we can’t glorify what we’ve done as deeds for the people, I know that. I’m not entirely proud of our actions.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: That’s what I’ve been ruminating on. I suppose it’s not something you need to know, though.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: We simply need to do what suits where we stand.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: Yup. Both you and I are doing this for our own satisfaction n’ desires.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: And that’s about it. Claiming to stand for a higher cause is just an excuse.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: We both have things we have to protect or take.

Dialog.Title: L’heure du Loup
Dialog.Content: If you got it, let’s get this started.

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Social Sciences

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: What a marvelous sight. This looks like a perfect place to get sentimental over.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Hello there~ As much as I’d like to treat you to a cup of coffee, the circumstances say otherwise… What a shame~

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: I don’t believe said circumstances are relaxed enough for such jokes, either… You’re being quite tender. Do you always tend to be that soft?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: If we can’t avoid facing each other, there’s no need to make it more tense than necessary, now is there? Though I do often hear that I’m carefree~

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: Don’t make me laugh. Is that supposed to be a humble brag?

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: Would you like me to introduce her?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: No need~ I’ve got the gist of what’s going on.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: …This puppet was made after that person, wasn’t it~?

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: It’s a gorgeous piece of work, if I do say so myself. I’d even dare say that it’s my magnum opus.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: In terms of appearance?

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: If I had to pick, that wouldn’t be it. I’m not the sort of man that finds beauty in shapes put together in an arbitrary fashion.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: Even if a puppet were as beautiful as a master’s sculpture, I wouldn’t love its look in itself.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: They’re neither disgusting… nor attractive to me. They simply are. I have no particular feelings about how they look.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: What do you make your puppets for, then?

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: The thoughts and emotions I hold when I craft them…

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: A resentment towards the City for driving me to this desperation, and a blind anger for the rich.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: A glimpse of hope that I can bring back my precious son whose life they took.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: Bitterness, and… a yearning for vengeance toward Roland, the man who rid me of that hope and pushed me to despair.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: I wrap the emotions I couldn’t outwardly express in a human string and shape them.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: I take out the useless chunks of meat… and fill their insides with the emotional baggage I’m carrying.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: I can breathe easy after I indulge in my craft… That’s when I feel alive at last.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: Do you see how dear the puppets are to me now?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Stuffing your emotions in them, huh…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I don’t understand it, but I won’t bother giving my thoughts on it~

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I’m still not very happy about what you did to Roland, though.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: He robbed me of a person I cherish… so I gave him the same treatment.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: You said he burned down your whole lab, yeah?

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: Yes. My son was lost in that fire, not a piece of him left to salvage. …Are you trying to express sympathy for me?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Nah~ We aren’t close enough to worry for each other.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I was just curious~ I wanted to know if vengeance was your only goal in coming here.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: Although we have minor differences, all the members of our ensemble strive to reach the same place.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: Vengeance pointed at Roland was only an intersection we happened to come across on our way to it. It was never at the center of my motive.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: Well, thanks to him, I won’t have any regrets making my way through.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: It’s tragic that we all have our own little stories, isn’t it?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: We can’t be free of guilt no matter what we do.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: That’s precisely why one has to focus solely on what they want to do.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: I too wish for a world in which individuals are free to express the flavors they want to exude~

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: But, is that freedom really the kind that frees one from all responsibility of what they do?

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: People who want to live for others can’t take a step forward themselves.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: There’s a limitless range of dreams individuals want to bring out.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: And you must know that the possibility of pursuing your own freedom while you consider everyone else is nothing short of a myth.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: If one were to take into consideration the width of the potential each person has…

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: …Never mind, that’s for you to think about. After all, that’s not the kind of world I want to see.

Dialog.Title: The Puppeteer
Dialog.Content: I’m not here for a leisurely debate, so let’s get to business now.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Yeah~ That is a good point.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: Well then, fellows. As usual… let’s receive our guests.

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of Philosophy

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: This place feels like a whole ‘nother world.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I bid you welcome, unfamiliar child.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Ah, you can skip the introductions. I heard enough about your kind and what you do here.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: The power to manifest a physical space… I’d almost believe it if someone said this was a Singularity.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: A space full of stars… Like the ones shining over the City, huh…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: I would like to hear what you think of the stars.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: They say stars are like a compass on the sky that gives guidance to people.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: In that case, are the Stars of the City guiding lights dictating where the City should go…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Or are they representations of the City itself?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Are these stars shining over the City, or is the City reflected in them…?

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Does that matter? They’re forced interpretations attached to them either way.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: To me, a star is nothing more than a dot on the sky.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: And they give off a forbidding impression like they’re looking down upon us from the highest post…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: That’s what a star means to you, I see.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Many alluring tales are told of stars, but when you observe one up close, you’re setting yourself up for disappointment. Isn’t that what a star is?

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: I have no interest in such pathetic things. I didn’t rise to a Star because I wanted to.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Perhaps most beings who have become stars did so simply by following their wants, much like you did.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: You’re right. I only did what I wanted to do, walking along a dry trail.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: We simply quenched our desires just like your kind always do, yet they feared us to an unreasonable degree.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: “Bloodfiends”. “Blood-red Night”… Those names plainly show how they perceive us. Even though they know that we’re fundamentally humans like them.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: But I suppose there’s no use in complaining about it at this point.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Then, I must wonder how you felt when you craved for human blood if you still consider yourself one.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Feelings? I just kill and be done with it. I’ve got to do something to slake this searing desire that gradually grows stronger.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Ah, I guess I wasn’t always like this.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: At first, for myself… I bit into the flesh of other humans and drank their blood for my own sake.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: The severe thirst was one thing, but there was also something I wanted to know.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Have I become a beast that must feed on human blood like the others… Or am I just being a pathetic runaway, escaping from reality?

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Or, am I a mere human who has gone insane from the fiendish circumstances and twisted desires?

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: I would continually ask myself that question as I chewed on their flesh. What could be the reason?

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Maybe I was desperate to convince myself. I used to be an ordinary human being living an ordinary life, after all.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Eventually, I found myself looking for a conclusion for a matter that won’t have one.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: I guess I still had a grip on my sanity at that time. Even as I shoved bits of flesh in my mouth from the irresistible thirst, I constantly questioned myself, telling myself that this was wrong.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Well, it’s all a story of the past. It’s funny to look back on those times.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Are you amused by the image of your past self seeking an answer for a question that has none?

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: I doubt your kind would’ve viewed us any differently even if I continued to think about it.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: I don’t expect your kind to take a sudden shift and change your views on us or anything.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: If they want to live their lives as they see fit, then they won’t stop me from doing the same.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Think about it. We can’t roam the street in peace; we’re forced to live in the darkness. What sins have we committed to deserve this treatment?

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Why must we suffer to ensure that your kind lives a painless life?

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: We’re humans just like you. We just look a bit different.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Seeing your kind lavishly pursue your desires while we’re left in the dark… It’s only natural for me to feel indignant, isn’t it?

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: If they won’t reconsider how they see us no matter what we do, we’ll gladly stop holding back and live as we like.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: That is an intriguing tale.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: Intriguing? Ah, whatever… If that’s how you wanna take it.

Dialog.Title: Blood-red Night
Dialog.Content: What you think or what kind of world you want to make are all irrelevant to me anyway, no?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You would be right. Now is the time to fight for where you stand.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Be prepared.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: Greetings. I am Hokma… I am the librarian who guards this floor.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: You are quite the polite gentleman. This was unexpected from the Library that was rumored to be brutal.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: Not to mention, this place also has a… rather quiet and moody atmosphere. Not bad.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: The silence and emptiness makes it hard for one to believe that the macabre atrocity of turning people into books has taken place here on multiple occasions.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: …May I ask who the people behind you are?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: They’re the assistant librarians who shall aid me in receiving you warmly. You may introduce yourselves to each other.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: But of course. My name is Pluto.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: …I believe this was a floor dedicated to the topic of religion. What is religion in your view, if I may ask?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: What could it be. I would say that it is what one firmly believes in, and a state of mind that gives motivation and significance to their deeds.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: Is the power of a belief really limited to endowing one with such a mindset?

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: Doing deeds for the good of this world doesn’t inherently make one a good person, and neither does committing a bad deed make one evil.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: Even if one performs misdeeds, they can be a virtuous person, and can be forgiven for anything…

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: I’d argue that belief and religion are what enables one to think that everything they conceive and accept is right.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: In that context, faith in religion has to be a truly selfish and cruel concept.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: I suppose your statement isn’t entirely incorrect.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: Do you agree with it?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: I could say it is true that an unsteady and crumbled mind is prone to absorb improper beliefs.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: Unsteady, you say…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: …Do you have anyone or anything you believe in?

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: I cannot say for sure. I tend not to place faith in what I cannot see.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: In fact, I cannot be entirely certain of if I am here in reality or in a dream, or if I am actually looking at you or not.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: I even question the fact that I am here, standing on my own two feet. After all, it may be a mere product of an illusion.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: Humans can fool their own senses; how can I believe in what does not exist, let alone worship it?

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: That would be akin to sensing coldness upon touching a hot object, and vice versa.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: For instance, what if… there was a deceptive entity that masks one’s perception of the world with falsehood?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: Regardless of the reality, if one perceives it in a certain way, that would become an undeniable truth.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: Even if it turns out to be false, the fact that one believes it to be the truth at the moment… remains stalwart.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: To believe in something, one must believe in themselves and their view on it.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: You’re speaking specious words.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: I only realized that day that I cannot blindly trust what my eyes show me.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: In that moment of the past, I was made a fool.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: The shallow promise that our safety would be secured… The thin piece of contract is what cost me everything.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: Had he not saved me, I might have drowned myself in resentment toward the whole world… and met my end.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: And now, I plan to take the path he intends to open.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: If I had to state one thing I believe in… It would be Sir Argalia and the new world he shall create.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: Let me ask you what makes you put faith in him.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: If I can close my eyes and open them again to a new world forever devoid of lies… I will readily believe in him.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: And I hope you will come to appreciate the City when it becomes such a place.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: I will refrain from stating my assessments. My opinion matters little to you, after all.

Dialog.Title: Yesterday’s Promise
Dialog.Content: Well, if you say so. In that case… be prepared.

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Library – Floor of General Works

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Come on, Roland. Are you really going to keep your mouth shut before me?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: What do you wanna hear? We both know each other’s goals.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: You aren’t still being oversensitive because we hurt Angela’s feelings, are you?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Of course you aren’t. You’re just mad because a wrench was thrown into your oh-so perfect plan.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Rich coming from the man pulling this shit…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I wonder what you’re implying by “this”… Something wrongful?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: See, I can’t understand the distinction between right and wrong…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: The “right things” are ingrained into human beings in the name of common sense, hindering their progress and making them live unhappy lives.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …What horseshit are you spewing this time.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: You know, what they often call “definitions”.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Why does time flow in one direction?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: That’s because you think time has to flow one way.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Why is that the right thing? What makes something “right”… Why do we have to bother deciding what’s right?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Maybe, it’s because there’s an entity that drew those lines so we can’t progress any further…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Why is the concept of “rightness” trying to restrain human desires? Why is it impeding our advancement? Are the questions I asked.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I raised these questions, and worked out an answer shortly after. And now… I’m going to announce it to all of the City.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: So let me get this straight; you’re rambling that it’s possible to go back in time and shit if that mold is broken?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You’re wasting your life on useless ideas.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: No. It will be possible. You just can’t get out of the mold because you’re firmly holding onto it, doubting the possibility.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Without this mold, our ascent will reach infinite heights. This is no hypothesis, it’s a fact that can be proven.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Having realized that, our ensemble now stands before you like this.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You talk big, but you just wanna get rid of the pain you’re carrying in truth, am I wrong?

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You want to crush me, the City, and most of all Angela for taking Angelica’s life.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Hahaha… Do you think I’m like you? You might have seen through one thing, but you can’t see further than that.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I’m not planning to return my suffering in full.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Ah, I won’t deny all of it, though. Perhaps I did think of doing it at first. My only light was taken from me twice…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: For a brief moment… I felt all kinds of emotions before that piano. Despair, obsession, rage, sorrow…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: But, it took no time for those feelings to dissipate into nothing.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Everything… yes. Everything seemed beautiful afterwards.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Was it truly a tragedy that I lost her? Who defined it as tragedy?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Roland, you may still be blinded by wrath, but I made the decision that I will care not about those feelings anymore.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: As if. You’re clinging onto the justification that it’s for Angelica’s sake even now…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: That’s not it, Roland… I’m going to send off Angelica with this performance.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I won’t be going on an unsightly rampage, unlike a certain someone.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: That Angelica can justify the pursuit of an ambition tainted by unclean desires is just a dreadful excuse now.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: If you realized that, why don’t you also drop the excuse about this being her dirge or whatever.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Humans can be so finicky, no? That’s why I’m preparing this performance.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: This performance will be my final enlightenment, and I’ll share it with everyone at the same time.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Moreover, this dirge will be the last thing I do for Angelica.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: I still have no idea what you’re saying. I guess your bullshittery levels are off the charts for me, huh?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: The existence of things we cannot understand is what makes life fun.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: I’ll continue to chase after what lies beyond my understanding after this.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Which means I’m going to wield the power to ceaselessly move forward.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: To do that… I’ll have to take the power you’re keeping in your storage into my own two hands, isn’t that right?

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: …Let’s end our affectionate conversation here.

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: Haha. You’re still keeping those gloves…

Dialog.Title: The Blue Reverberation
Dialog.Content: How putrid.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Shut up.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: We managed to put a stop to that sicko and his gang of nutcases somehow.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Looks like their books are on another level, too.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: This is the end of the Invitation’s guidance. We’re at our final destination.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Congrats, Angela. It’s finally over.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: You’ve got a human body, so you don’t have to live as a machine anymore, right?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Indeed. I am free now. All the Light has been reclaimed.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I have gained a perfect human body… and freedom. I’ve made it with your help.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Thank you… Roland.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …All I need to do now is take my book from the Light.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: Alright, guess it’s time for me to finish this, too.

Dialog.Title: Servant
Dialog.Content: …Angela. You can guess what I’m about to do now, yeah?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: So it was no coincidence that you came to the Library, Roland.
You bet. The series of events leading up to this moment was the biggest gamble of my life.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I see. You helped me attain my freedom, but it wasn’t for my sake…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You just used me like a tool.
C’mon, don’t talk like you got nothing out of me. I never slacked off, y’know?
I gave it my all to support you until you reached your goal. It’s mutual exploitation, at the very least.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Did you get the result you wanted?
Well, I got enough. The reason I’d come to the Library was to figure out the cause of the phenomenon that created Distortions like the Pianist.
And to find out who was responsible for it.
As such, all obvious signs… point to you, Angela.
None of this would’ve happened if you hadn’t thrown a tantrum in your last moment.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Why didn’t you try to stop me or kill me right away, then?
…First off, you were simply unkillable when I first met you.
Second, I wanted to know why you made the choice you did.
Third, I thought that maybe you could make a different decision that I couldn’t.
And fourth, to bring you the greatest loss—the greatest suffering… at the very end of it all.
Right now, you’re completely human. You can feel pain as its whole, and experience death.
I learned here that you went through your own fair share of torment, frustration, and loss.
I can understand why you made the choices you made.
And seeing you start to contemplate your aim as time went by… I thought that maybe there was room for another option.
That maybe, just maybe, you might choose a different answer…
And if you somehow did by that smallest chance… Then I might have been able to find a different solution myself.
But in the end, you didn’t.
Sure, the pain I went through may be a speck of dust compared to your million years of despair… But so what?
That day, I swore to myself before that damned piano.
I swore that I’d make the City experience the same sorrow of loss—of the frustration that I felt when it took my world away from me.
…The same as you.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Then… Who will pay for the misery I went through?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: There was nothing else I could do; all I knew was to make them suffer the same pain…
You’re asking me for an answer?
If I knew the way… and if I could choose it, I wouldn’t have done this drivel.
I do know one thing for sure: This is what happens when you try to wash blood with blood.
Angela, you have to feel the same sorrow as mine…
No. You have to feel even worse than that. You took Angelica from me—she meant the world to me.
I sat on my hands as I watched the people I knew die, and I even killed my old friend with these shadowed gloves, just for this moment.
All for this very moment… I’ve been suppressing my emotions, forcing a pained smile.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …Seeing you shed tears is an unfamiliar sight.
I’m done with the façade now.
I’ll do everything I can—in ways beyond your imagination—to give you the most painful death possible.
And I’ll do it right before you take the final step to your freedom. I’ll rob you of everything.
You’ll reap the whirlwind for what you’ve sown…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …I only want to be compensated for my suffering.
…What’s this now? You’re acting weak all of a sudden?
Are you finally starting to hesitate when it’s almost over?
Nah… can’t be.
You’ve got power and knowledge, and now a proper life as a living being on top of it… You just don’t wanna give up what you finally took hold of.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: At least I used a method that isn’t forcef—
You used the same logic as when you’d stolen the Light. You used it to kill those who came to the Library in the name of fair price.
You didn’t even stop to think about the consequences of your actions.
That’s how you’ve always been. You don’t give two shits about anyone other than yourself.
I don’t blame you, though. I just can’t.
It’s how the City works… That’s that, and this is this.
That’s why I’m going to kill you strictly with the mindset of the City folk.
What I need to do is kill you and take my revenge; what you need to do is kill me and get the freedom you want.
We just need to have a simple, raw state of mind as we fight each other.
So I want you to stop getting any funny little ideas and stick to your desire for freedom and vengeance.
I have nothing but my sorrow…
And I want nothing more.
It has been, it still is, faithful to me.
Why should I begrudge it, since during the hours…
When my soul crushed the depths of my heart,
It was seated there beside me?
O sorrow, I have ended, you see, by respecting you,
Because I am certain you will never leave me.
Ah! I realize it:
Your beauty lies in the force of your being.
You are like those who never left The sad fireside corner of my poor black heart.
O my sorrow, you are better than a well-beloved:
Because I know that on the day of my final agony,
You will be there, lying in my sheets, O sorrow,
So that you might once again attempt to enter my heart.
A dimwitted egoist whose sight is limited by their own selfishness… A proper fool chasing after immediate results…
That’s what you are. And who I am…
The same logic that dictates us was bound to be our downfall one day…
If we really cared for ourselves… Neither of us should have made this choice.
It won’t last long that way… Being selfish isn’t about keeping an eye on yourself and nothing else.
We had to take a good look at the things around us and engrave them in our hearts.
Everything is interlinked, after all…
Just kill me already. Hesitating at the end is a bad habit that’ll get you offed out there.
…Alright. Why don’t you hesitate a little longer, then. I’ll take your head as soon as you let your guard down…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …Roland, I’m going to let go. Someone has to break this cycle, ultimately…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: After all, even I couldn’t escape the treadwheel turning for this City.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: And if I have to be entrapped in more of such cycles, perpetrating deeds similar to what I’ve done… I…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I don’t think I could live that life further…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I would continue to be crushed under the everturning wheel; the only difference would be how harshly it smothers me…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Achieving freedom was meaningless in a world like this.
…What? After all the mess you’ve caused… You’re gonna let go? Now?
Were you struck by some huge revelation or something?
What about all the people who faced an unavoidable death in this damned Library…
All those people I’ve killed… What’ll become of them?!
What was my determination and my despair for… these sacrifices I’ve made…
You HAVE to want something, dammit!!!
You can’t break it off so easily…
You’ve come too far for that…
Someone who doesn’t even have a full-fledged desire… has no right to take so much blood and power…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I… feel their weight now, and it’s too much for me to bear… I thought this would be the last time.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I sincerely mean it… If I shut my eyes again and shed blood one last time… I thought I would be free to live as I want.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Alas, I could never be truly free as long as I was chained to the bonds of the City.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You, I, and this Library are soaked in the blood of many.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: All the actions I took in pursuit of freedom only sped the treadwheel.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I convinced myself that it was an inevitable sacrifice I had to put up with, for the sake of my freedom and amends for my agony…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: And once this was over… I wanted to stop taking precious things from anyone.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I know what loss and pain are, how they feel…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: However, the wheel that is this City is powered by those, crushing everything in its path.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: If I have to snuff out what belongs to me with my own hand in the end…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: And if life requires me to spill the blood of others, or lets my own blood so that I may live on…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I’d much rather remove my grip on this goal…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: At the very least, I refuse to die under the wheel.
…You can’t just undo what you’ve done.
You extort from others once, and you have to keep doing it… What were you gonna do if you lack the resolve to commit even that…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: The books, the librarians, the Library… and finally, my own freedom.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I’ll let go of them all first.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I will no longer cling to them. I won’t try to keep them in my clutch anymore.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: If I give it all up… then I can reverse this…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: At least, those who died in the Library can be brought back.
…Is that the answer you chose?
When you can just walk out of this place and go wherever you wanna go? When the exit from this prison is finally open?
For one million years, you’ve been waiting for the day when you could exact your revenge… And still, you can make that choice?
Even when the thing you’ve desperately wished for is just ahead of you?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Yes… I made this decision by dint of my own will entirely.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: This will be the first wish and the last choice I make… since I’ve become free from all restraints for the first time.
That still won’t make me forgive you… I’m not supposed to forgive you.
You can’t just let go of stuff on your own, that’s not how it works in the City…
…It’s selfish to do that.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Let me ask you one last favor.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I am going to leave myself vulnerable for a short while.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Expelling everything I’ve absorbed until now won’t be a simple feat.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Could you leave me be while I do that?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I’m asking you as a dear friend.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …If you still consider me a friend, that is.
…You do know I can just kill you in the meantime instead, right?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I won’t stop you, but don’t worry.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: When I’m done, everything will go back to the way it was; I’ll disappear without a trace.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …There isn’t much time, so I’ll get started right away.
…How could you lay down your own goals?
How can you… cut it off before anyone else?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: This is the end of the line, Roland. I suppose this is another sorrow I must overcome.
Yup. We all just have to look at our own agonies and nothing else…
Congrats, Angela.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Thank you so much. I’ll move onwards to the next stage of my life.
Hey, seeing you cry is a rare enough sight.
Holding such misery, I’ve made it to this point at last.
With eyes that can shed tears, I shall laugh as I watch the city cry.
That book taught me many things:
The way to give Abnormalities physical form, to set them free.
The way to liberate the Sephirot by bestowing wholly human bodies upon them.
The way to restore the consciousness and flesh of all the employees of Lobotomy Corporation.
The way to attain the strength I need to live on in the city…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: It’s time you accepted your fate and returned to books.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You know better than anyone else that it’s pointless to oppose me in the Library, don’t you?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Literature
Dialog.Content: Malkuth… Netzach… Yesod… They’re all dead…

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Language
Dialog.Content: So this is your final choice, huh.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Soc. Sciences
Dialog.Content: What a shameless person you are, Angela…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Maybe this is what I should have done sooner.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: It was silly of me to make a deal with you…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I wouldn’t have to feel this heartache, had I not made the offer that day and lived by myself.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: You take the liberty of giving us life, only to bring death again… You’re truly unwise.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Religion
Dialog.Content: Furthermore, you are regretting your own decisions…

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You tried to interrupt me, so I did what I had to do.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: After all, you chose to stand against me with the flesh and freedom you’ve gained.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You could’ve walked away and disappeared from my sight, and I wouldn’t have harmed you.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: It is amusing that you should mention that.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: You have earned a human body and the freedom for which you sought so earnestly, yet you will not take a single step onto the soil outside the Library.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …That’s how fickle the human mind can be. Wouldn’t you agree?

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: Indeed, you are right.

Dialog.Title: Patron Librarian - Philosophy
Dialog.Content: …Let us dance our last dance together.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I want this to be your final and permanent slumber.
Ayin… Your dream will plummet to the ground… I bet everything on it…
To stake everything means to devote all that I have.
Why did I yearn for a human body so strongly?
It’s only a burden for my vengeance.
I am a librarian, one who watches the fall of the City from the ivory nest I erected.
It will grow into a library that devours all the knowledge and life of the City.
The Library encroached on the southern quarter of the City.
No one could dare stop its violent growth.
It ceaselessly killed people, enriching the spire of knowledge without falter.
It shines over the City, brighter than any other star.
For thirteen years, the Library enshrouded the City.
That was one grand job you did with all these dangerous monsters you’ve gathered, Miss Librarian of Death.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …Good work.
“A monster should behave as one…”
I trusted and followed you, knowing nothing.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: How many colleagues of yours… the so-called ‘Bookhunters’ have you killed?
I’ve lost count.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: And countless more people will die in the future.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I know humans. I learned the secrets of mankind that the City had been hiding from them.
I’m sure you do… And I know you.
Thank you for all your hard work. Please die once and for all.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Thank you for putting me to rest, o child who had no name.
Even the brightest star fades someday.
It will eventually be felled by man, just like any other star.
As tonight, again, the stars are brushed by the wind.
…You can’t just put an end to it, Angela.
It’s not something you could decide on your own like this!!!
…Angela. The reason I give you a painless death, as opposed to my initial plan…
…Well, let’s call it a last bit of consideration for you—as my friend. Alright?
It’s all over… Angelica…
As Angela’s head toppled to the floor, the Library crumbled with her.
A solitary man stands in the middle of the City.
Next to him was a machine soaked in red.
The Library vanished, as if it were an illusion all along.
And the man disappeared into the City once again.
Did you hear the news? Our big man’s returned.
Roland? Really, after all those years of creating mayhem…
I thought he quietly wound up six feet under or something.
He’ll be dead sooner or later. He’s done too many things for him to handle the consequences.
So? How’s he doing these days?
Maybe I’ll go pay him a visit for old times’ sake.
Heard he spends each day drowned in drugs and alcohol. Taking filthy jobs like he’s possessed or something.
That fool’s changed too much. He’s not worth seeing. I bet he’ll disappear again soon enough.
Few people can go on without changing. I mean, just look at us.
A man drifts down the gutter.
Numerous weapons dig into the man’s back.
A club that belonged to a stranger.
A limb that belonged to a nemesis.
A dagger that belonged to a colleague.
A lance that belonged to a friend.
These countless instruments of harm are the karma he bore.
I know that on the day of my final agony,
You will be there, lying in my sheets, O sorrow,
So that you might once again attempt to enter my heart.
What did I tell you, Roland… You’ve killed too many…
I warned you that if you relish murdering so much… you’ll lose yourself…
Just like that, the man sank into oblivion—in black silence.

Group.GroupName: The Reverberation Ensemble Transforms - The Blue Reverb: Third Encounter

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: …What’s this? I thought I passed away…

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: I can remember… turning into a book…

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: Oho, could it be an encore~?!

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: Neiiigh, bray!!

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: Bawk bawk bawk, cock-a-doodle-doo~!!! Arf rarf arf, woof woof woof!!!

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: This must be the outcome of your choice.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: Thank you, Angela… and Roland.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: With these new forms you gave us, we can perform once again.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: I see. This form…

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: I can’t wait to get back into the City! I wanna meet people!

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: I feel like I can make the best taste mankind’s ever known right now!!!
Look, Angela didn’t make this choice for your sake, you know?
She just chose what she actually wants for the first time.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: You appear to be invigorated, much more so than the last time we saw you.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: It seems we all are brimming with a similar vigor. I can sense a noble power seeping into my body.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: In this light, we shall achieve perfection.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: This is how it feels. Naked, yet able to be myself at last…

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: This is the moment I’ve been waiting for… I was born for this moment!

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: A warm echo unlike what I’d heard… it pervades me…

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: I can hear a sound that’s much closer to my heart. I can hear the motion of the City…!

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: Yes… It’s that light! I won’t miss this final opportunity given to me…

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: Aight. With this strength… Let’s go for ‘nother round.
There’s no way in hell I’m letting you lay a finger on Angela.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: We’ve reached the pinnacle. …We can go anywhere we want from here.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: If only you could have protected Angelica with the same resolution.
Yeah, yeah~ Keep running your mouth, see if I care.
I’m thinking of following my good pal along the path taken as she pleases.
Making sure to take a good and long look at the things around me this time.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: So you accepted it in your own way.
Definitely not your way.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: Indeed… In the warmth of this light… let’s have a dance together. It will be beautiful and perduring.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: Attention, everyone!

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: We’ll claim the final fraction of the light that will make us whole.

Dialog.Title: The Reverberation Ensemble
Dialog.Content: Would you please allow me to conduct this finale?
Boy, you’re still the same nutjob even when you’re a freak.
Whew, I guess that wraps things up…
What are you gonna do now?

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: What to do…
Looks like your body did turn back into a machine.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Yeah… It was nice to be able to forget the things I should forget, if for a brief while.
You said the people who’ve turned into books in the Library are gonna come back, right?
But so far, the only ones to revive were the Blue Reverb and his cronies.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: They’ll regain consciousness to find themselves lying somewhere in the City, as if waking up from a long slumber.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: There wouldn’t have been any uncertainty, had you not intervened at the last moment.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Thanks to you, I have no idea when or where the people will reawake.
So they’re still coming back anyway, yeah? That’s a relief. I had a feeling this would work out.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Why did you do such a thing if you weren’t even certain?
Doesn’t hurt to do something I actually want for the sake of myself.
I got sick of weighing profits my whole life.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: You still have something you’re hiding from me, don’t you?
…The Purple Tear told me one thing before I made the jump here.
“When you get in there, it’ll be nice in several ways to do what you want without letting anything hold you back at the end, kid.”
Seeing you slowly vanish in the light, her words hit me.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: It sounds as if she anticipated everything.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Was it by the Purple Tear’s assistance that you could intrude into the Library?
Yup. You read in her book that she can jump between dimensions or whatever, yeah? I was honestly doubtful about her whole deal, but I eventually decided to get some help from her.
And… Here, you dropped this.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …It’s the list of wishes I wrote.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: I don’t think I can accomplish half of the things written here with a body like this, though?
Well, that’s something we gotta start figuring out from now on.
There probably won’t be one absolute answer or whatever.
There are as many people as there are stars out there, all intertwined with one another.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: And every one of them has a different story, a different answer to tell.

Group.GroupName: The Head, The Eye, The Claw

Dialog.Content: By the by, I thought this Library fell to bits for the most part… But it looks like its power is still there, right?
There’s gotta be a horde of people watching for the chance to raid this place out there, but no one has broken in so far.
I find that peculiar as well.
…That, Angela, is because this Library is the shell of your mind and consciousness…
Or E.G.O, as you call it.
It’s the consequence of making a decision that only a human could make…
One that couldn’t be further from what a resident of the City would choose.
…How long have you been here?
A visitor from the Head, huh… The Eye and the Claw, too…

Dialog.Title: Executioner of the Claw
Dialog.Content: Keep perfectly still, or you’ll be torn apart.

Dialog.Title: Executioner of the Claw
Dialog.Content: Remember. Even you of all cityfolk can be ripped to shreds in your current state.
Damn…

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: You may have concluded your own little tales, but the Distortion still continues to grave its mark on the City.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: That new color has permeated the City much too profoundly.
…So now the Head is gonna hold us accountable for the phenomenon, is that it?

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: No one could be held responsible for the Distortion at this point.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: It breaks my heart to think that it might shift the ecology of the City we had cultivated with care.
If so, what brings an agent of the Head here? And why so late?

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: We’re here to expel you and your Library from the City.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: And to retrieve a certain… degraded colleague of ours.
You mean…

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: This structure in its entirety will be driven out and relocated to the Outskirts.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: The Library has already become an Impurity of the City. We couldn’t stand by any longer.
Are you disturbed by its powers?

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: Not quite.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: The sole reason is you: Angela.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: An entity that isn’t human entertained thoughts that only a human should have.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: You poor machine… No matter how much you contemplate and enrich your mind, you cannot become human if you aren’t born as one.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: When I thought you might turn into a human at the end, you let go of all you had during that critical moment.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: Had you fully become a human at the culmination of the ordeal, the City would have been more willing to accept you, alas.
I don’t care if I have to stay as a machine.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: A machine with a heart has no place in this City.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: You cannot break free from your origin which defines you.
Why does that matter? I’m the only one who has a say in defining MY identity. I don’t need any flimsy husk to do it for me.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: How contemptible that your line of thought is so dangerously close to what a human must aspire to reach.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: You’re further demonstrating why we cannot let you be.
For someone who loves to preach humanity, you sure seemed fine with letting Distortions cause many a scene in your precious backyard, hm?

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: By all manner of means, Distortions are one of the many aspects of humanity. Their existence is not wholly wrongful from our point of view.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: It was simply time for them to emerge.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: Are they not more bearable than a meager machine putting up the charade of being human?

Dialog.Title: Beholder of the Eye
Dialog.Content: So do yourself a favor and throw away that crumpled piece of paper. You’ve done something so cute so nervelessly.
And what if we made you kick the bucket here?

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: The expulsion will still take place as planned. It’s inevitable.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: This matter goes beyond you and the Library; L Corp. itself was a stain and a blemish to the Head.
No wonder it is. To trounce over L Corp’s Singularity and its end goal, you dispatched an Arbiter by the name of Binah…
No, it was Garion, wasn’t it—regardless, it ended in utter failure, did it not?

Dialog.Title: Beholder of the Eye
Dialog.Content: Garion did such a sloppy job dealing with it. And now the chasm has grown too wide.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: Angela… The machine with the mind of a human.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: The door mustn’t be closed because of something like you.
If I’m understanding this right, you wish to put me to death and kick the Library out into the Outskirts, is that correct?

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: You’ve guessed right.
I exist in this place as myself, standing on my two feet with my own strength. I have no problem brushing off the bullshit you’re spewing on my doorstep.
And… You sure are verbose company, just like Binah.
You always add needless comments as if you just can’t help it.

Dialog.Title: Arbiter of the Head
Dialog.Content: …Executioner.
I thought the Library ceased pretty much all of its functions?
As that Arbiter said, the Library is my E.G.O.
In that case, I can perform such feats without breaking a sweat.
Although this is only a temporary retreat, similar to how guests are greeted.
We’re finally receiving guests from the Head itself, huh… I guess these are the last ones we’ll get to greet from here.
It seems they are. I don’t have to stay in this Nest, anyway.
Good for us, saves the trouble of packing stuff up to move!

Place.PlaceName: Location: The Former Nest of L Corp.

Dialog.Content: The expulsion will begin in 10… 9… 8…
The Outskirts look much more barren than I had imagined.
I guess that’s how it is here. Now what to do…
I plan to live on. And I plan to change.
Change what?
Well, my vengeance… hasn’t ceased entirely. I’m still eager to see it through.
I’ll continue to write books, and reopen the Library at some point.
It likely won’t resume immediately, though.
…Really?
Before anything else, I’ve decided to change course.
From now on, I’ll properly face who I should direct my anger at.
Tragedy and suffering not unlike what we went through would keep happening on a daily basis in the City.
Thus if that’s the case, I want to know why such pain is perpetuated.
I don’t think I’ll ever be able to part with my resentment and wrath otherwise.
Oh yeah, like the whole treadwheel thing you mentioned…
A word of advice as former cityfolk: It won’t be an easy road to take.
You’d have no idea where to even start.
If you ask me, it’s as natural as water flowing… In a City full of humans—tragedy, violence, and loss follow as a matter of course.
I’m still going to give it a shot. Even though the journey will be quite long…
Perhaps this is one of the ways I can repent for what I’ve done.
Of course, the Library will be run in a different way from how it was up to now.
That is this, and this is that.
…Hmm, that is this… and this is that, huh.
What about your list then?
Since the circumstances have changed, I’ll have to rethink my wishes.
Sadly, I won’t be able to taste that “sick” meat stew with this body.
That’s a huge shame…
Putting that aside, isn’t it time you let me in on your secret now?
What do you mean?
The biggest surprise you’ve had here.
Oh, that… You somehow remembered it.
I can remember anything, you know.
Sigh… This one’s really personal.
We have all the time in the world. I can wait years for your answer.
Alright, fine!
…Mmh. I actually wanted to write a book.
About what I’d seen of the City, and its people.
Though I gave up ‘cause I had no talent in writing whatsoever…
My writing was just too crude. I couldn’t show it to anyone.
I’d love to give it a read.
…Laugh at me if you want. A grown man like me, wanting to write books. I’d laugh at myself, too.
It’s not laughable at all. Though I do find it surprising…
…Recording the City and the lives of its people, huh?
Don’t tell the other librarians! This stays between you and me, alright? Keep it zipped!

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: …Alright. Shall we write a book together this time, Roland?

Dialog.Title: Friend
Dialog.Content: It would be my honor, Miss Director.

Dialog.Title: Library Director
Dialog.Content: Wrong, try again. You should know by now that’s not the right way to address me, don’t you?

Dialog.Title: Friend
Dialog.Content: Sounds good to me, Angela.
